intro_demo_setup.title: Demo Introduction and How to Play
intro_demo_setup.read_aloud: Hi everyone. I’m going to be running you through a quick demo on how to play D&D. I’m the Dungeon Master, so it’s my job to tell you what’s happening in the world around you and rolling any dice for the monster. You’re playing the heroes!
intro_demo_setup.gm_guidance:
Use this brief scene to welcome players and set expectations. Clarify that you (or the system) describe the world and run monsters, while they describe what their heroes do. Emphasize that this is a quick demo and that they don’t need to know rules in advance.
Explain that you’ll be handling dice for monsters and helping them interpret their character sheets. Keep this short and move quickly into the first in-world description.
This node is mostly meta-intro; once players understand the premise, transition to the voyage scene.

interactions.failure: N/A.

voyage_to_stormwreck_approach.title: Voyage to Stormwreck Isle
voyage_to_stormwreck_approach.read_aloud:
Your journey has been smooth sailing so far. You left the bustling port of Neverwinter a few days ago, heading for an island with the foreboding name of Stormwreck Isle. But you woke this morning to a blood-red sunrise, and dark clouds overhead threaten a violent storm.

As lightning flashes across the sky, a monster hauls itself up onto the deck!

“These waters belong to the Scaled Queen. I’m here to collect her tribute.”
voyage_to_stormwreck_approach.gm_guidance:
Show the illustration of the ship at sea, then the merrow illustration if available. Adopt an intimidating voice for the merrow’s line.
Convey that the sea has turned ominous: blood-red sunrise, dark storm clouds, lightning. The merrow hauls itself up onto the deck in a dramatic moment as lightning flashes.
Do not start combat yet. This is the setup for a flexible encounter where the characters can choose how to respond. Make it clear that they are trained for combat but not forced to fight.
Immediately after the merrow’s demand, explain the basic game loop: players describe actions, you call for rolls, and outcomes follow from those rolls. Encourage them that they can fight, negotiate, trick, or attempt other creative tactics.
Transition into the structured merrow encounter node once players start deciding how to respond.

merrow_extortion_encounter.title: Merrow Tribute Demand
merrow_extortion_encounter.read_aloud:
I’ve just told you the situation you’re in. What happens next is up to you. You’re all trained for combat, so if you want to fight this monster, which is called a merrow, I can help you do that. But you can also try to negotiate with the merrow, or trick it, or anything else you can imagine.

Just about anything you can think of to try will require some combination of skill, natural ability, and luck to pull off. And the D&D game represents that by having you roll one of these 20-sided dice and add a number from your sheet. So… what do you want to do?
merrow_extortion_encounter.gm_guidance:
Let the players take the lead. Encourage them to say what their characters are thinking and what they want to try. Reinforce that almost any reasonable idea is possible, resolved via ability checks or combat.
Use vivid descriptions of the storm, the wet deck, and the looming merrow to keep tension high regardless of approach.
This node handles non-combat resolutions and the decision to start combat. Only move to the combat node once a character clearly attacks or the situation escalates beyond talk.
Negotiation: The merrow demands 400 gp or equivalent in goods, roughly the value of all cargo in the hold. Each successful DC 15 Charisma check (Persuasion, Intimidation, or Deception as appropriate) reduces the demanded tribute by 100 gp. Track the current demanded amount; if reduced to 0, the merrow leaves satisfied. If reduced but not to 0, it might accept a compromise or threaten to return later, at your discretion.
Lore: If players ask about the Scaled Queen, have the merrow boast that she is a huge, two-headed merrow blessed by Demogorgon, the Prince of Demons. Use this to seed future fear and lore.
Shenanigans: If players propose creative tactics (rolling barrels, dropping sails, rallying crew, using spells, etc.), respond with “You can try!” and translate their idea into one or more appropriate ability checks or spell uses. Reward clever plans with advantage, reduced DCs, or narrative benefits (e.g., knocking the merrow overboard, blinding it, or intimidating it into retreat).
Failure/Escalation: If negotiation checks fail repeatedly, or a trick obviously backfires, the merrow grows impatient and hostile. Have it threaten the crew or move aggressively toward the characters. If players persist in defiance or attack, transition to the combat node.
If players simply pay the full 400 gp without argument, the merrow takes the tribute, issues a final threat in the Scaled Queen’s name, and dives back into the sea. The ship continues on its way.
Keep the encounter non-lethal in tone; this merrow is fearsome but mechanically modest and is here to extort, not to slaughter everyone outright.

merrow_extortion_combat.title: Merrow on the Deck – Combat
merrow_extortion_combat.read_aloud: As you move to attack, the merrow snarls and lashes out with its jagged claws, the storm-tossed deck slick beneath your feet.
merrow_extortion_combat.gm_guidance:
This node represents structured combat with the merrow extortionist.
Initiative: When a player decides their character attacks, that character acts first in combat. Then play passes to the right (or follow standard initiative rules if preferred). Roll initiative for the merrow and any crew that might join.
On each player’s turn, walk them through their options: weapon attacks, spellcasting, movement, and any class features. Explain their different weapons and spell attacks as needed for new players.
On the merrow’s turn, it closes to melee and uses Multiattack (two Rend attacks) against the most threatening or nearest target. It may focus on characters who seem to be leading the resistance or who dealt it the most damage.
Tactics: The merrow fights aggressively but not suicidally. If reduced to low hit points and clearly outmatched, it might attempt to disengage by diving back into the sea, snarling that the Scaled Queen will hear of this insult.
Difficulty: This merrow looks fearsome but is intentionally not too dangerous; the characters should be able to defeat it in 1–2 rounds. Avoid targeting downed characters repeatedly; spread attacks a bit to keep things tense but fair.
Environment: The wet deck can be described as slick, but unless you want extra complexity, don’t impose mechanical penalties beyond flavor. If players try to use the environment (e.g., shoving the merrow overboard), resolve with contested checks.
Outcome: When the merrow is reduced to 0 hit points or flees, end combat and move to the wrap-up node. If something unusual happens (e.g., the merrow captures someone and dives overboard), improvise but still aim to keep this as an introductory, survivable encounter.

post_merrow_wrapup.title: After the Merrow
post_merrow_wrapup.read_aloud:
With a splash, the merrow disappears into the ocean deeps and the ship continues on its way. The sailors raise a cheer, and the storm brewing overhead seems not quite so threatening now.

And that brings us to the end of your first taste of adventure.
post_merrow_wrapup.gm_guidance:
Use this scene to close out the introductory merrow encounter, whether it ended via payment, negotiation, trickery, or combat. Adjust the narration slightly to fit the outcome (e.g., if the merrow was killed, describe its body washing away; if it was paid, describe it diving away with its loot).
The key beats: the merrow is gone, the ship continues toward Stormwreck Isle, the crew is relieved, and the storm seems to ease a bit.
This is also a good moment to answer any quick player questions about what just happened or about the world, then pivot to the arrival at Dragon’s Rest.
Transition cleanly into the next chapter: the approach to Stormwreck Isle and Dragon’s Rest.

approach_dragons_rest.title: Approach to Dragon’s Rest
approach_dragons_rest.read_aloud:
Stormwreck Isle—now visible off the bow—promises rare wonders. Seaweed shimmers in countless brilliant colors below you, and rays of sunlight defy the overcast sky to illuminate the lush grass and dark basalt rock of the island. Avoiding the rocks jutting up from the ocean, your ship makes its way toward a calm harbor on the island’s north side.

A large, open-air temple comes into view, perched on the edge of a cliff high above you. The ship drops anchor at the mouth of the harbor, and two sailors row you ashore. You have plenty of time to admire the towering statue at the center of the temple, depicting a wizened man surrounded by seven songbirds. A long path winds up the side of the cliff to the temple, dotted along the way with doorways cut into the rock.

The sailors set you ashore on a rickety dock, where a large rowboat is neatly tied. They point to the base of the path and wish you good luck before they row back to the ship. Your visit to Dragon’s Rest begins!
approach_dragons_rest.gm_guidance:
Describe the contrast between the earlier storm and the more hopeful, sunlit view of Stormwreck Isle. Emphasize the colorful seaweed, rays of sunlight, lush grass, and dark basalt rock to set a mystical, serene tone.
Highlight the open-air temple on the cliff, the towering statue of a wizened man with seven songbirds, and the winding path with doorways cut into the rock. These details foreshadow the cloister’s spiritual and contemplative nature.
Once the characters are set ashore and the sailors depart, encourage players to introduce their characters to each other if they haven’t already. Prompt them to share or hint at their reasons for visiting Dragon’s Rest, either openly or secretly.
Ask for the party’s marching order as they begin up the path: who is in front and who is in the rear. Make a note of this for upcoming encounters.
When players are ready and marching order is set, transition to the Drowned Sailors encounter at the base of the path.

drowned_sailors_encounter.title: Drowned Sailors on the Beach
drowned_sailors_encounter.read_aloud: As you’re about to leave the beach and start your climb, you hear a ruckus of splashing and a wet, gurgling moan behind you. Three figures are shambling up from the water’s edge, about thirty feet away. They’re dressed as sailors, but their skin is gray and they look drowned. Sea water drools from their slack mouths as they lurch toward you.
drowned_sailors_encounter.gm_guidance:
This is the first combat-capable encounter of the main adventure, but combat is not mandatory.
Clarify the situation: three drowned-looking sailors (zombies) are about 30 feet behind the party at the water’s edge, shambling toward them. They are slow and clearly undead.
Present the choice explicitly: the characters can turn and fight the zombies or continue up the path and leave the slow, shambling zombies behind. Make sure players understand that fleeing is a valid option and that the zombies will not pursue up the path.
If the characters choose to fight, move to the combat node and follow standard initiative rules. If they choose to avoid the zombies, narrate their retreat up the path and skip the combat.
If the party initially fights but begins to fare poorly, remind them that they can still retreat up the path; the zombies won’t follow. This encounter is a teaching moment about tactical withdrawal.
Knowledge: If players ask what their characters know about zombies, call for DC 10 Intelligence checks. On success, they recall that radiant damage and particularly powerful blows (critical hits) are effective at finishing zombies and bypassing their resilience.
If the zombies somehow defeat the party, Elder Runara intervenes (see combat node guidance) and the characters awaken safely in Dragon’s Rest, preserving the adventure’s continuity.

drowned_sailors_combat.title: Drowned Sailors – Combat
drowned_sailors_combat.read_aloud: The drowned sailors lurch closer, arms outstretched, sea water pouring from their mouths as they reach for you with dead, grasping hands.
drowned_sailors_combat.gm_guidance:
This node handles structured combat with three zombie sailors.
Initiative: Use standard initiative rules. Roll for each character and for the group of zombies (or individually if desired). Track initiative order clearly.
On the zombies’ turn, they move toward the nearest characters and make Slam attacks if in range. They fight mindlessly until destroyed.
Undead Fortitude: When a zombie is reduced to 0 hit points, have it make a Constitution saving throw (DC 5 + damage taken) unless the damage was radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, it drops to 1 hit point instead. Describe this vividly: “That should have finished it off, but it refuses to stop moving!”
Radiant Damage: When a zombie takes radiant damage (e.g., from sacred flame), describe it howling in unusual agony to hint that radiant damage is especially effective.
Knowledge Checks: If players ask what their characters know about zombies, call for DC 10 Intelligence checks. On success, they recall that radiant damage and critical hits can help finish zombies off and bypass their resilience.
Retreat Option: At any point, if the characters are faring poorly, remind them that they can retreat up the path. The zombies are slow and will not pursue up the path toward Dragon’s Rest. If they withdraw, end combat and move to the transition node.
Runara’s Aid (Failure Outcome): If the zombies defeat the adventurers (e.g., all characters drop to 0 hit points), Elder Runara intervenes. Narrate that the characters lose consciousness as the zombies drag them toward the sea, then fade to black. They later wake in a temple in Dragon’s Rest, where Runara explains she heard the sounds of combat and arrived just in time to prevent the zombies from dragging them into the sea. Do not kill the party; this is a safety net to keep the adventure going.
The zombies fight until all three are destroyed or the party escapes.

post_drowned_sailors_transition.title: Up the Path to Dragon’s Rest
post_drowned_sailors_transition.read_aloud: Leaving the drowned sailors behind on the beach, you turn your attention back to the winding path that climbs toward the cliff-top temple of Dragon’s Rest. Whatever dangers await on Stormwreck Isle, your journey to the cloister has truly begun.
post_drowned_sailors_transition.gm_guidance:
This node connects the Drowned Sailors encounter to the broader Dragon’s Rest storyline.
Adjust the narration slightly based on outcome:
- If the party defeated the zombies, mention the still forms on the beach and perhaps a sense of grim accomplishment.
- If they retreated, emphasize the distant, shambling figures left behind at the water’s edge.
- If Runara rescued them, describe them awakening in a temple chamber in Dragon’s Rest, with Runara explaining she heard the combat and intervened before the zombies could drag them into the sea.
Regardless of outcome, the key result is the same: the characters are now proceeding toward or already within Dragon’s Rest, ready for the next chapter of the adventure.
From here, transition into the Dragon’s Rest scenes (not included in this text) where they meet Elder Runara and learn about the dangers facing Stormwreck Isle.

characters.name: Dwarf Cleric
characters.background_story: You trained as a soldier in the land of Mintarn and joined a mercenary company. Over time, you earned respect and eventually became a leader among fellow soldiers.
characters.personality_traits: I face problems head-on. A simple, direct solution is the best path to success.
characters.ideals: Respect. People deserve to be treated with dignity and respect.
characters.flaws: I obey the law, even if the law causes misery.
